title-group.article-title: A randomized controlled trial of electrostimulation effects on effussion, swelling and pain recovery after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction: a pilot study

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, Yuzuncu Yil University, Van, Turkey
2Department of Orthopaedics, Yuzuncu Yil University, Van, Turkey
3Department of Orthopaedics, GATA Military Hospital, Ankara, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Levent Ediz, Yuzuncu Yil University, Medical Faculty, Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, 65100 Van, Turkey Email: leventediz@gmail.com

abstract.p: Objective: To evaluate rehabilitation results of electrostimulation especially on joint effusion, swelling and pain recovery after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.
Design: A randomized controlled trial; the assessor was not blinded to the group allocation.
Setting: Orthopaedics-traumatology and physical medicine-rehabilitation departments.
Subjects: Twenty-nine consecutive patients underwent anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

Interventions: Both groups began the voluntary exercise protocol one day post-surgery. The intervention group (n = 15) also received 30 sessions electrostimulation treatment protocol started four days after the operation.

Main measures: Numerical bulge-dancing patella signs for effusion assessment; differences in circumferences of the mid-centre of the patella between operated and non-operated knees for swelling assessment. Aself-report of average daily resting pain assessed by visual analogue scale; Intenational Knee Documentation Committee scoring system and Tegner Activity Scale for subjective response assessment.

Results: Twenty-six subjects including 13 patients from the intervention group completed the study. Significantly less effusion and swelling were determined in the intervention group after seven days (1.8 ± 1.3 versus 2.4 ± 1.7 for effusion and 1.7 ± 1.2 versus 3.4 ± 1.5 for swelling) to 12 weeks (0.2 ± 0.7 versus 0.6 ± 0.8 for effusion and 0.2 ± 0.8 versus 0.8 ± 0.9 for swelling) postoperative (P < 0.05). Patients treated with electrostimulation had significantly lower pain scores from seven days up to 12 weeks after the operation (P < 0.05).

Conclusion: Electrostimulation along with exercise therapy appears superior to exercise alone regarding knee effusion, swelling and pain recovery after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction. Still, there is need for further clinical studies using a radiologic method to demonstrate this effect of electrostimulation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction is a frequent operation and rehabilitation is one of the most important factors in obtaining good clinical results after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.1 Quadriceps atrophy and strength loss often exceed 20% and 30%, respectively, during the first three months following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction because of unloading of the knee joint and restricted weight bearing for two weeks after surgery.1–3 A significant decrease in thigh and calf girth at three weeks after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction was reported in a previous study.1 Therefore, anterior cruciate ligament rehabilitation protocols focus on strengthening patients’ quadriceps femoris and hamstring muscles.2,3 Indeed, it is crucial that patients start to exercise the quadriceps femoris, hamstring and triceps surae muscles during the early postoperative period in order to maintain muscle strength and prevent muscle atrophy.

One additional conventional choice for solving muscle atrophy problems is electrical muscle stimulation (electrostimulation).4–11 Electrostimulation contracts skeletal muscle through transcutaneous electrodes that depolarize underlying motor nerves. In previous studies, researchers mostly focused on electrostimulation effects on muscle atrophy prevention and muscle strength after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction surgery.7–11 The effect of early electrostimulation on joint effusion-swelling and pain recovery after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction has not yet been evaluated. However, effusion, swelling, lymphatic oedema and pain regularly occur after anterior cruciate ligament surgery.6 Most of the reviewed articles do not address joint effusion and swelling after anterior cruciate ligament surgery. However, these two factors cause pain and limit range of motion, consequently playing a major role in rehabilitation after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction. Effusion and swelling should be minimized during any type of rehabilitation programme.7 For this purpose, coldpack and compression are often applied.7

Up to date, to the best of our knowledge, there is not any study in the literature evaluating the effects of electrostimulation on joint effusion, swelling and pain recovery after anterior cruciate ligament surgery. The aim of this current study was to assess the effects of 30 sessions of an electrostimulation programme adding to an exercise programme on effussion, swelling, pain recovery, range of motion and muscle atrophy after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Between February 2007 and February 2011, 29 consecutive patients scheduled to receive anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction were enrolled in the study. Patients were recruited from the Orthopaedics and Traumatology Department of the Government Hospital, Van, Turkey. After giving their written informed consent, all patients underwent a preoperative examination and were then randomised into two groups by an independent doctor using the sequentially numbered, opaque sealed envelopes (SNOSE) method described by Doig et al.12 Inclusion criteria were age 18–40 years, normal body weight (calculated body mass index between 19 and 25). Patients presenting with varus/valgus deviation of more than 5°,13 revision surgery, posterior or collateral instabilities larger than grade I, as well as osteoarthritis larger than grade I were excluded. Additionally, patients with meniscus lesions requiring surgical intervention which would change the postoperative rehabilitation programme were not included. Patients in group A (n = 14) recevied only exercises for six weeks post-surgery. This group did not have placebo electrical stimulation. Those in group B (n = 15) received exercises along with electrical stimulation for six weeks postoperatively. All patients were prescribed diclofenac sodium 50 mg/day for seven days after surgery. Patients were allowed to put coldpacks on the operated knee and could take 500 mg paracetamol if needed for pain control from the seventh postoperative day.

When the patients had recovered their full range of motion after the initial anterior cruciate ligament injury, anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction was performed. All patients underwent non-anatomical single bundle anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction using four-stranded autogenous hamstring tendon fixed with EndoButton (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy Inc, Andover, MA, USA) in the femoral tunnel and Intrafix (DePuy Mitek Inc, Raynham, MA, USA) in the tibial tunnel.

Apart from electrostimulation treatment protocol started from the fourth day post-surgery in group B, the two groups followed the same standard exercise rehabilitation protocol based on Shelbourne et al. from the first day to six weeks after anterior cruciate ligament reconstriction surgery.14,15

The quadriceps femoris, tibialis anterior muscle, triceps surae and hamstrings were selected for electrostimulation therapy (Intelect Advanced Therapy Stim, Chattonooga Group, Hixson, TN, USA). Impulses were applied transcutaneously through six rubber electrodes (each electrode 6 x 8 cm in size) on the operated lower extremity in extension position with the patient lying supine in a bed. Figure 1 shows electrode placement. Maximally tolerated level of stimulus intensity (range 65–100 mA) was performed to individual patients. The intensity level was individually increased as high as possible, without causing discomfort. The electrostimulator current waveform was at a frequency of 30 Hz (Hertz) with a pulse width of 300 μs with a a duty cycle of 10 s on and 20 s off for a period of 20 min (30 sessions, five consecutive days in each week for six weeks) to produce contractions in the lower extremity muscle groups without involving movement of the joint.

caption.p: Stimulating electrodes placement. Longitudinal orientation used in this study.

sec.p: The follow-up examinations were all performed by one of the study doctors thoroughly trained in knee examination, not blinded to group allocation. Each patient was examined on the first, seventh and 14th days, in the eighth and 12th week and six months after surgery. Physical examination focused on effusion-swelling, pain assessment, extension deficit, range of motion and thigh atrophy. The contralateral, non-operated knee served as a control.

Effusion was assessed on the basis of bulge and dancing patella signs and reported as 3 (>60 cm3 – tight capsule), 2 (25–60 cm3 – visible), 1 (<25 cm3 – palpable by smoothing out the joint capsule), or 0 (no effusion).10 Circumference was measured at the mid-centre of the patella to assess swelling. The contralateral, non-operated knee served as a control. Differences in circumferences between operated and non-operated knees were used as measurement of swelling.

A self-report of average daily resting pain was documented using a visual analogue scale. The scale consists of a 100 mm line labeled from ‘0’ on the left, representing ‘no pain’, to ‘10’ on the right, indicating ‘maximal pain’. The participant placed an ‘x’ on the line that best represented their current pain status. Measurements were made in millimetres.

Standard goniometric assessment was performed bilaterally to document active knee flexion and extension range of motions in supine position. Measurements were reported in degrees and performed in the sagittal plane. Each lower extremity was measured independently with three measurements taken for each motion, and the average value was used as the result value for knee flexion range of motion. Extension deficit was reported as side-to-side difference.

Circumference was measured at 10 cm proximal to the upper patellar margin and 10 cm distal to tibial tuberosity to determine atrophy. This measurement correlates significantly with isokinetic strength testing.16

Subjective responses of cases were derived using International Knee Documentation Committee scoring system and Tegner Activity Scale. Tegner activity level scale measures the highest level of activity that an individual case participated in (low activity level: 0–3; moderate activity level: 4–6; and high activity level: 7–10).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All results were given as mean values with standard deviations calculated using SPSS 13.0 software. Student’s t-test for unpaired samples was used to compare interval scaled mean values, Mann–Whitney U test to compare ordinal scaled data. A P-value of <0.05 was considered significant. Chi-square test was used to compare number of patients in groups or subgroups.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Thirteen patients (11 male, 2 female) from group A and 13 patients (10 male, 3 female) from group B completed the study. Three patients (2 from group B, 1 from group A) were excluded (lost to follow-up or emigrated). See Figure 2 for the study flowchart. No patients were excluded from the study because of the side effects of the treatment protocols. Baseline and demographic data comparison of the patients who completed the study are shown in Table 1. There were no significant differences between these two groups in terms of demographic data and baseline comparisons.

caption.p: Baseline comparison of the study parameters of the patients who completed the study

sec.p: On the seventh day after the operation, group B (exercises + electrostimulation) had significantly less effusion and swelling than group A (exercises alone) (P < 0.05). There were similar results from 14 days up to 12 weeks postoperatively (P < 0.05). See Table 2 for further details.

caption.p: Effusion, swelling and pain status of the groups. Numerical bulge-dancing patella signs for effusion assessment10; differences in circumferences of the mid-centre of the patella between operated and non-operated knees for swelling assessment; a self-report of average daily resting pain assessed by 100 mm visual analogue scale

fn.p: Difference between mean-mean; CI, confidence interval.

sec.p: Patients treated with electrostimulation and exercises (group B) had significantly lower visual analogue scale scores than patients treated with only exercises (group A) from seven days (P = 0.012) up to 12 weeks (P = 0.033) postoperative. Table 2 shows daily resting pain recovery of the groups.

Mean range of motion did not differ significantly throughout the study between groups. But mean differences in extension deficit at 14 days, eight weeks and 12 weeks proved significant differences in favour of group B (exercises + electrostimulation group). For further details see Table 3. No statistically significant differences were detected in mean knee flexion.

caption.p: Knee extension deficit of the groups and thigh atrophy measurement after operation. Knee extension deficit (in degrees) assessed by side-to-side mean difference. Thigh atrophy assessed by circumference 10 cm proximal to upper patellar margin: mean differences from contrlateral non-operated knee measurements (in centimetres)

fn.p: Difference between mean-mean; CI, confidence interval.

sec.p: The side-to-side difference in circumference at 10 cm proximal to the upper patellar margin was measured to compare thigh atrophy. There were significant differences between the groups at 14 days and eight weeks of the treatment (P < 0.04, P < 0.03, respectively). There was no significant difference in terms of calf atrophy (P > 0.05). Table 3 shows thigh atrophy measurements of the groups.

Tables 4 and 5 show objective and subjective International Knee Documentation Committee scores and Tegner Activity Scale. Twelve weeks postoperative, the mean International Knee Documentation Committee subjective knee score was significantly greater in electrostimulation group (group B) (P = 0.036). Differences in mean subjective evaluation scores of International Knee Documentation Committee were non-significant at the preoperative and sixth month evaluations. There were no significant differences in terms ofnumber of patients in International Knee Documentation Committee and Tegner Activity Scale between the two groups at 12 weeks and sixth months after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

caption.p: Pre- and postoperative International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) scores
Number of patients according to International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) Grade and Tegner Activity Level before surgery and at six months after operation

tr.th: Tegner Activity Level 6 months after operation

fn.p: A, normal knee; B, nearly normal knee; C, slightly abnormal knee; D, abnormal knee. Tegner activity levels: low activity level: 0–3; moderate activity level: 4–6; high activity level: 7–10.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although both electrostimulation and exercises are common strategies used to contract thigh musculature, the results of this study provide evidence that electrostimulation initiated four days after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction surgery can provide more decreases in effusion, swelling, pain, extension deficit and can prevent muscle volume loss greater than exercise alone. To the best of our knowledge this is the first study reporting effects of electrostimulation on joint effusion-swelling after anterior cruciate ligament recontruction.

The literature about effusion-swelling after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction is sparse. Combination therapy of cooling and compression is suggested to overcome effusion-swelling and lymphatic oedema which regularly occur after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.6 Mayr et al.17 investigated brace effect on effusion-swelling assessed by, similar to our study, the difference in midpatellar circumference between operated and non-operated knee. They found the water-filled soft brace was superior regarding effusion-swelling. Our study also provides evidence that the addition of electrostimulation yields more decreases in effusion-swelling than that of exercises alone after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

Electrostimulation interventions may reduce pain.18 We could not find any study in the accessible literature evaluating the effect of electrostimulation on pain recovery and extension deficit after anterior cruciate ligament surgery. In this study, patients treated with electrostimulation presented with less pain assessed by visual analogue scale and less extension deficit.

Less extension deficit in the electrostimulation group in our study could be due to improved extension strength. Recently Hasegawa et al.11 reported that early electrostimulation improved extension strength significantly after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction. Therefore, in the light of our results and literature data the use of electrostimulation could be suggested additionally to control pain and to achieve less extension deficit during acute and subacute terms after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction. We used a measurement of thigh circumference 10 cm proximal to the upper patellar margin to detect thigh atrophy which correlates significantly with isokinetic strength testing.15 We found significant difference between groups in favour of patients treated with electrostimulation.

There are some controversial results in the literature regarding the effects of electrostimulation on muscle volume and strength following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction surgery. Delitto et al.10 determined that patients in the electrostimulation group showed higher extension and flexion strength and torque when compared to subjects in the voluntary exercise group. While Lieber et al.19 found that 50 Hz electrostimulation and voluntary muscle contraction treatments, when performed at the same intensity, are equally effective in strengthening lower limb muscle groups that have been weakened after reconstruction of the anterior cruciate ligament. However, Arvidsson et al.9 found less atrophy of the vastus medialis after electrostimulation. Also, Fitzgerald et al.20 found that addition of electrostimulation treatment to classical rehabilitation resulted in more increases in quadriceps torque output after 12 weeks of rehabilitation when compared to patients who underwent rehabilitation without electrostimulation. Our results confirmed significant positive effects of electrostimulation training following anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction. Our findings indicated that electrostimulation not only prevented muscle atrophy following anterior cruciate ligament surgery, but also resulted in more decreases in effusion-swelling, pain and extension deficit.

These results might be caused by our early start timing of electrostimulation. In most of the previous studies, electrostimulation started after lower limb muscles had already begun to lose volume and strength. For example, in one study, researchers compared electrostimulation with exercises in patients two to six weeks after anterior cruciate ligament surgery and found equal effects of the two rehabilitation regimens.19 We could find only one study evaluating early implementation of electrostimulation (on the second day after surgery) to prevent muscle atrophy and weakness in patients after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.12 Dupont et al.21 started electrostimulation within six weeks of the knee operation and found that the electrostimulation group demonstrated significantly smaller loss of isometric knee extension strength than the control group, but the treatment was not enough to prevent muscle atrophy. In contrast to most of the mentioned studies above, we began electrostimulation on the fourth postoperative day and were able to sustain muscle volume.

Limitations of the current study are (a) small sample size (n = 26), which inevitably leads to limited statistical power, (b) joint effusion-swelling has not been assessed by a radiologic method such as ultrasound or magnetic resonance imaging and (c) the same frequency (30 Hz) was selected in the current study in different muscles (quadriceps femoris, tibialis anterior muscle, triceps surae and hamstrings). These muscles have different proportions of fibre type (I or II) and could be on the same appropriate frequency for all these muscles, although the same frequency was used in different muscles in most of the electrostimulation trials after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction. The outcome assessor was not blinded to the patient groups. However, the data were sufficient to demonstrate the effects of electrostimulation on effusion, swelling and pain after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

list-item.p: Early electrostimulation after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction surgery can provide more decreases in effusion, swelling, pain and extension deficit, and can prevent muscle volume loss greater than exercises alone.
This could result in rapid recovery of the patient and ease the work of rehabilitation team after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
